title: Bayesian Inference Framework
description: Bayesian inference is a method of statistical inference that updates beliefs about parameters based on observed data using Bayes' theorem.
learning_objectives: Apply Bayesian inference to parameter estimation problems
Compute posterior distributions using Bayes' theorem
Understand the role of prior beliefs in inference
Connect Bayesian inference to Active Inference

content.overview: Bayesian inference provides a principled framework for updating beliefs in light of new evidence. It formalizes the process of learning from data by combining prior knowledge with observed evidence to produce posterior beliefs.

bayes_theorem.posterior: P(θ|D) - Updated belief after seeing data
bayes_theorem.likelihood: P(D|θ) - Probability of data given parameters
bayes_theorem.evidence: P(D) - Probability of observing the data

inference_process.likelihood_modeling: Model how data depends on parameters
inference_process.posterior_computation: Apply Bayes' theorem to update beliefs

types_of_inference.model_comparison: Compare different models using Bayes factors

connection_to_active_inference.belief_updating: Bayesian inference as perception in Active Inference

examples.name: Active Inference Perception
examples.description: Bayesian belief updating in Active Inference

advantages: Natural for decision making under uncertainty

interactive_exercises.description: Simulate Bayesian inference for coin flip experiment
Compute posterior distributions for simple models

common_misconceptions.misconception: Bayesian inference is subjective due to priors
common_misconceptions.clarification: All inference requires assumptions; Bayesian makes them explicit
Frequentist methods also make assumptions, just different ones
Modern methods make it feasible for many applications
